Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: threat and non-threat. Threat is a statement that someone will be hurt or harmed, especially if the person does not do something in particular.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Enough already.  Cut the head off this snake.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Disgusting comment, I pity anyone who has to live with you.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Bravo!  Bravo!

Encore!! Encore!! Encore!!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is clearly unrelated to threat.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: ... after shooting her with her own gun.

Comment: Also, the issue of "feeding an ever-growing world population" starts with managing the global birth rate.  Our earth has a do-not-exceed carrying capacity, and the boom-to-bust overpopulation / dieoff cycle is well recognized by biologists.  We may be dangerously close to that scenario.  

Fish is high-quality protein, but fish farming on the scale needed to feed a hungry world should be driven by the ecology of the process.  Just like land agriculture, the need is to grow the most food, sustainably, with the least burden to the planet.  That means fish that are capable of turning food into fish flesh most efficiently, raised in operations that consume the least resources and generate the least pollution.

If butterfish farming can meet those criteria, fine.  If not, it shouldn't be touted as the potential solution to world hunger -- and should be conducted on an appropriate scale.

1) Just because something is critical for life doesn't mean that more is better. Oxygen is critical for life, but too much will poison you. C02 is a greenhouse gas not a pollutant. 

2) The actual concentration of C02 is 0.04%, 100 times what you said. Carbon's role in greenhouse warming is significant and demonstrable. C02 only emits certain wavelengths of infrared radiation so the more of those wavelengths we find, the larger the contribution of C02. Those wavelengths are dominant compared to other greenhouse gases.

3&4) Climate models have predicted rising surface and ocean temperatures. That's happened. Don't confuse the actual science with things said by celebrities. Very few specific predictions have been made by credible institutions other than temperature estimates. 

5) Sea levels are rising and will continue to do so at rates proportional to the melting at the poles.

6) Your point?

Comment: Regrettably but also inexcusably, fleeing the scene of an accident if you were driving drunk is arguably a rational choice given current events and real-world outcomes.  I'm absolutely a believer in the old saying that "flight equals guilt" but look at what actually happens if you do:

(1) There is a remote chance you'll escape scot-free and never be held to account.

(2) If you are later caught, then due to the time elapsed, it may be impossible to prove you were driving over the Hawaii 0.08% BAC limit (for those age 21 and up).

(3) Charges of fleeing the scene of an accident or failure to render aid often don't survive the legal process and are frequently bargained away in plea deals.

Running away from an accident you caused is reprehensible but not all alcohol abusers and bad drivers are dummies.  Some of them read the paper and watch the local news too.

Comment: Sigh. My comment was made late at night, after a long plane ride and was Pretty Much satire.  Why satire? Because both sides are kinda absurd. 
Eugene consistently creates an awkward if  not hostile environment for homegrown, or at least West Coast businesses, tiny, small, large or whichever. My peanut gallery comment applies to both sides, both sides means right wing and left wing. Of course the reality is different than right versus left.  For example, just one among perhaps hundreds, the restriction on the size of signs a downtown business may display before paying an exorbitant fee. The work around for this is easy enough, but it's still a Pain.  Don't get me started on the plastic bag ban.  It makes sense in cities next to large bodies of water, such as the oceans, or the Great Lakes. But Not Here. The plastic bags have a much better reuse life span and are more frequently reused. I think the ban on dogs downtown is stupid. It's policy theater. What next, cat leash laws? Reear!!

Comment: Hey, pseudo--"anomie" doesn't mean what you think it does.  The primary meaning is breakdown of customary social and ethical norms.  It also sometimes refers to personal alienation from society that results from such breakdown.  It doesn't mean "the absence of any emotion at all"; the word for that is "alexithymia."  And it doesn't mean "depression". Both of these are clinical entities.  "Anomie" is strictly a sociological concept.

Not one penny of federal money is used for abortions.  Federal money that goes to Planned Parenthood is reserved for women's health needs such as gynecological screening and contraception, of which PP is one of the major providers to poor women.  Of course the government doesn't want states to accept money designated for those needs and then simply deny it to PP because a religious clique controls their legislatures and wants to make a grandstand play for their fans.

Reread Schopenhauer, idiot.  And stay away from Pound--he's too hard for you.

Comment: I think that some commenters here may need to get out and circulate a little more. I'm a 60-something white male of Scottish-English heritage, and I agree with almost everything this author said. I remember being taught by my relatives when I was young to beware of the Irish, because they were dirty and swore too much, the Italians, because they were too emotional and would kill you over a perceived slight, Finns because they ate too much fish and their houses smelled "funny", etc. etc. Fortunately, I didn't believe them and made good friends of members of all ethnic groups where I grew up. Later, I worked in the health field and found myself surrounded by a whole new group of "new" Canadians, all of whom were swept up in the opportunities Canada offers. I've been ill for awhile now and can no longer work, but my friends from those days always check to see how I am doing, bring presents, and tell me that they are praying for me to God, Jesus, Allah, Buddha, what-ever. I love them all.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: Depends what the definition of Hate you use.  In normal English, hate is pretty broad and can just mean intense dislike for something, which should always be an individual's right.  The laws about Hate Speech are more narrow and only apply to speech which incites and encourages discrimination or violence against groups.  So one can hate Islam, and be deeply critical of Islam which might result in other people coming to hate Islam also.  But one cannot encourage people to discriminate against muslim people, as I understand the law.  This idea of putting Islamaphobia into law might be breaking new territory, if it has any teeth - making it risky to use our freedom to hate against us.  That endangers free speech, imho - heck it endangers free thought, as phobias are purely a fear in the mind and its thoughts.

Comment: 'Tis an ill wind blows no good. And O'Leary is nothing if not windy. 

True, this is a party that - in its most recent incarnation as government - was undoubtedly the most undemocratic in our modern history. It habitually abused the Elections Act, Parliament, the Supreme Court and the Constitution.

But it begs credulity to hint O'Leary is the white knight the Cons need to lead them out of the wilderness. Fraudsters undermined his leadership prospects - and he outed them. Good for him. But don't ask us to believe this brash populist is just itching to strike a blow for liberty, equality, fraternity. 

To be fair, O'Leary isn't Trump - even if he shares Trump's ego and worship of money. And yes, his tv persona may be exaggerated, but I defer to his co-host Arlene Dickinson who said "Somebody who is as self-interested and opportunistic as Kevin is not somebody that I want to have run the country."

Comment: When the facts demonstrate that the government is, in fact, trying to take our firearms, it isn't paranoia.

In 1967, the city of New York passed a law that required all rifles and shotguns to be registered.  Subsequently, in 1991, the city also banned semi-automatic rifles and using the registry already in their possession they issued notifications to those owners that their firearms must be removed from the city, disabled, or turned over to the authorities (ie: confiscation).  In 2013, they sent another round of letters demanding more removals or confiscations.

Also in 2013, Connecticut passed legislation that required gun owners to register their firearms and magazines.  Although few actually complied, in 2014 the State started low volume confiscation of those items registered by the people who complied with the legislation.

These are just a few examples, and there are even more in other countries, Australia and the UK to name a few.

Comment: The Supreme Court of Canada has certainly made a big mess.

What they did was markedly foolish. They chose to put into motion a set of events that would set criminals free, to the detriment of everyday citizens, if the other arms of government did not meet the strict timeline the Judges imposed.

In other words, they made the egregious error of setting up a mechanism that would ultimately make everyday citizens pay the price for government failure to meet their imposed and tight deadlines.

What a mess. And what a poorly developed ruling from the bench.

In future, when the judicial tail decides to wag the national dog, the tail would do well to set up the needed penalties and reprimands for the individual politicians who fail to meet the judges' strict timelines. That way the politicians, the objects of the court's ire, will bear the brunt of failing the judicial directive, instead of having everyday citizens pay the (too high) price.

Comment: In all these discussions of this subject, I bring the primary responsibility back to the judges who refuse to take control of proceedings in their courtrooms.

Mr. Butt references "aggressive" cross-examination.  Of course, every witness, including sexual assault complainants, should be available for rigorous cross-examination.  Whether that becomes "aggressive" is up to the presiding judge.  If defence counsel wants to challenge the complainant with an alternate version of what happened (say, with respect to consent) then the judge can and should caution counsel that they had better be planning to introduce evidence to support their alternate hypothesis or else that entire line of questioning is going to be shut down.  Judges currently have the power to do that.  No fishing trips or blind accusations.  In the vernacular, put up or shut up.

Of course, in most cases counsel won't want to introduce that alternate evidence because it would mean putting the accused on the witness stand.

Comment: This whole affair is ridiculous. The offer and acceptance of a re-enlistment bonus is not a case-by-case deal between a soldier and a recruiter. This was a program put in place because there was a shortage of trained personnel. These re-enlistment bonuses were offered to soldiers who had MOS (military occupational specialty) designations that were in demand. Each recruiter obviously had guide lines. Once a soldier agreed and signed a contract to extend his or her enlistment, the paperwork was reviewed at a higher level. It was clearly the military's burden to rescind the re-enlistment, promptly, if, after review, it found that it should not have been offered by a recruiter.Once the soldier re-enlisted and was utilized, it became a "done deal". These were contracts. Asking for the money to be refunded is absurd. These people stepped up and served. In many cases they were deployed into a war theater. Instead of trying to take their money back, they should be given a second bonus.

Comment: In general, soldiers are trained to fight other soldiers, not to slaughter civilians. Soldiers on the battlefield have not been seen in dense formation since breech loaders replaced muzzle loaders, other than some of the WWI slaughters that demonstrated the futility of attacking machine guns with massed infantry. As a result, automatic weapons fire ON A BATTLEFIELD is used primarily for suppression. Soldiers don't train for WWI scenarios because the enemy these days attacks with tanks rather than massed infantry. 

So, you are technically correct. Armies do not now field automatic weapons with the expectation of being able to mow down massed enemies, because the enemies just aren't that stupid. However, when automatic weapons first became available, and up through the end of WWI, armies did equip with automatic weapons precisely because they could cause "a lot more carnage".

Comment: The tax is based on nationality (non-Canadian citizen) not on "national origin," which is the language of section 15 of the Charter.

"15.(1) Every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right to the equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination and, in particular, without discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age or mental or physical disability."

For example, if the tax applied only to Canadians of Russian origin, it would violate the equality section of the Charter.  However, I can't see how a tax that applies only to non-Canadians would.  They might have more luck with the claim that such a tax isn't within the power of a province.

Comment: "The rest of the world is struggling to find balanced ways to reduce carbon emissions"?  Rubbish!  

China's commitment so far is to continue to increase it's carbon output till 2033, when it will begin to consider otherwise.

The Indian government says it will reduce carbon emissions 33 to 35% by 2030.  Sounds great eh?  Until you read the fine print . . . lower the rate relative to its GDP.  India's GHG emissions are soaring and will continue to do so.  

Now with the USA out of the game, Trudeau doubles down on his pledge to euthanise the Canadian economy with a carbon tax, even though Canada produces only 1.8% of global GHG's.  And Canada's vast boreal forests absorb more CO2 than Canada emits!  All this for mere symbolism. 

Trudeau is going to drive Canada's economy into the dumpster for a plan that, even if it succeeds, will do nothing to alter the rate or direction of climate change.

Comment: "It is the mark of an intelligent mind to be able to entertain an idea without accepting it."

It's the mark of an aggressively unintelligent mind to spout platitudes without considering whether they're applicable.  Your obvious assumption here is that this is the first time CherryCreekCrab has been presented with this idea.  The reason we don't "entertain" flat earth ideas is that they have been floated (as the article points out) since antiquity.  In the last several thousand years, these ideas have not evolved at all, and have only gotten easier and easier to debunk as technology has allowed us to travel around the globe, view detailed maps created via satellites, use handheld devices that pinpoint our locations, and on and on.  We can also just rely on common sense and note how quickly objects disappear over the horizon.

An intelligent mind entertains an idea until it's blatantly disproved, and then stops wasting time on it, regardless of how many idiots try to bring it up again.

Comment: Thank you, Mr Nordlund, for this important column. I note that you actually understate the history of this despicable practice. It wasn't merely the banks denying loans to minorities going back throughout history, but it was the stated policy of the United States government to do so. The creation of the Federal Housing Administration in the 1930s was designed to help white homeowners only. The regulations used a color-coded system for different "grades" of neighborhoods, and blacks and other minorities were explicitly prohibited from getting mortgages for those grades supposedly above their station. The practice ostensibly ended with housing reforms in the 1960s, but, as this column demonstrates, it still continues off the books. This is the dictionary definition of institutional discrimination, and we suffer from its legacy, all of us, to the present day.

Comment: I am not sure how you land at "nonsense". Those data are available and I think I have described them accurately. Compare population growth data against data on rents or real estate prices over the last 20-30 years. We had higher pop. growth when prices/rents were flat. Also, there is a net loss of people aged 25-45 and near zero growth of those 18-25. It's small, but it's growing in rate. As to ghost neighborhoods, that is somewhat anecdotal. But even the most ardent fans of this market that I know acknowledge that this phenomenon exists in swaths of the Richmond, West Van, the West side, etc.

Regarding economic growth, I agree that construction and real estate are providing a kick to our economy. I question its sustainability and the de-diversification of our economy (the % of BC's GDP related to these sectors is now ~1/3, effectively doubled from a dozen years ago). 

(cont'd)

Comment: On what grounds do you say that Trump's policy wasn't based on evidence?

The evidence* is that providing transgender surgery and hormones would cost the US military between $2.4 million and $8.4 million per year, in addition to the time lost. That's to cover the estimated 29-129 service members who would seek the treatment yearly. It's rational to ask, is that additional cost worth the small number of soldiers gained from it? While that matter is being studied it's reasonable to put a hold on transgender people joining the US military. And that's what Trump did. 

It's also reasonable to assume that, as did 18 other countries including Canada, the US military will conclude that allowing transgendered people to serve does not seriously impact the force's ability to function.

* The Implications of Allowing Transgender Personnel to Serve Openly in the U.S. Military - Rand Corporation

https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_briefs/RB9909.html

Comment: Whoever introduced that vile bird vetch into Alaska should be hung, drawn and quartered!  Talk about invasive!  I don't think I have seen any more ecologically damaging plant in Alaska to match it, including dandelions.  At least most invasive plant species in Alaska seem to stick to disturbed soil such as roadsides and lawns, but not this nasty plant --- I have been seeing vast swathes of it in relatively open woodlands as well, particularly in and around the area near the Palmer Agricultural Experimental Station on Trunk Road where it was presumably first introduced.  I've seen it climbing up and pulling down wild rose and mooseberry plants, and I shudder to think what our woods and roadsides are going to look like in another ten or twenty years if this bird vetch cannot be controlled (which it almost certainly cannot be at this point).
